Award.AwardTitle: Sum frequency studies of liquid interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kenneth Eisenthal is supported by an award from the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms program in the Chemistry division to develop and apply second harmonic generation (SHG) and sum frequency generation (SFG) as methods to selectively probe interfaces of fundamental scientific interest. The PI and his research group focus on the interfaces of noble metal nanoparticles with the liquids in which they are suspended. The central question they ask is "how do noble metal nanoparticles affect the photophysical mechanisms by which molecules in excited electronic states, located at the nanoparticle/liquid interface, dissipate their energy"? Using femtosecond SFG and SHG they probe the ultrafast decay of interfacial molecules in excited electronic states. Because of the special optical and electronic properties of noble metal nanoparticles new channels for energy relaxation become important. SFG and SHG are sensitive to interfacial molecules only and are not sensitive and thus not overwhelmed by the much larger population of molecules in the bulk liquid. Using SFG and SHG, they measure the vibrational and electronic spectra of interfacial molecules in their ground, excited singlet, and triplet states. The molecules of interest are the aromatic carbonyls because of their special photophysical and photochemical properties.


This research is of technological importance in developing methods and tools to probe the competing energy decay processes that directly impact the efficiency of solar cells, light emitting diodes, nano-electronics and nano-optics. These methods are relevant to a wide variety of fields, including emerging technologies in health care, electronics, nanotechnology and alternative energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As our understanding of biomolecular function increases, the need to detect equilibrium and dynamic interactions of biomolecular species, with ever increasing sensitivity and specificity, likewise grows.  To this end a new and novel nonlinear optical technique, based on second harmonic or sum frequency generation has been developed. This nonlinear method has the valuable characteristic of not requiring a label and furthermore is interface selective, which is very useful in studies of biomolecules at a membrane/aqueous interface and molecules tethered to a nano-microparticle surface. The method exploits the dependence of the generated second harmonic light on the electrostatic potential at the interface of microparticles with the aqueous solution in which they are suspended. A manifestation of an interfacial potential and its change in time was observed upon addition of a restriction enzyme to a solution containing the highly charged DNA biomolecule, bound to the surface of microparticles in the solution.  Initially the SH signal was found to rapidly increase with time as the enzyme induced a bending of  DNA, which is important in facilitating its reaction with other chemical species. This was followed by a much slower process, the cleavage of the bent DNA into two fragments. One remained attached to the microparticle and the other diffused into the bulk solution. It is only the  attached fragment that contributes to the charge density at the interface. In this way the interface potential changes, which in turn changes the intensity of the SH signal.

It is to be noted that most biomolecules, e,g, RNA, proteins, peptides,  and biological membranes, are charged, and thereby on complexation with other molecules, neutral or charged, effects a change in  the electrostatic potential that can be detected using the interface selective second harmonic  and sum frequency generation techniques.

It is also noted that an increasing number of laboratories around the world are now using this method to obtain interface potentials; a property that is central to understanding  the chemistry, physics, and biology of charged interfaces and their environs.
